Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, the scent of incense from the living room drifting in as my mother called for me. Today was the day of our family’s annual ancestral ceremony, and this year, I was expected to lead the rituals—an honor and a responsibility that meant everything to my parents. They believed it was my turn to uphold our traditions, to show respect and devotion in front of everyone. But as I scrubbed the counters, I glanced at my hands, raw and red from cleaning without gloves. My supervisor at the housekeeping job always reminded me: gloves must be worn for every task, no exceptions, for my own safety and hygiene. Yet, the ceremony required bare hands—no barriers between me and the sacred objects. My mother’s voice grew more insistent, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down. I wanted to make my family proud, but I also feared the consequences at work and for my health. My heart pounded as I stared at the gloves, torn between the expectations of my family and the demands of my job, unsure which part of myself I could let down.
